Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Elevated Carbon Dioxide, Nitrogen Metabolism, and Photorespiration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen is the mineral element that plants require in greatest amounts. A major source of nitrogen for plants is the nitrate that they absorb from soils. Research in the Bloom laboratory has established that rising CO2 (carbon dioxide) concentration in Earth's atmosphere inhibits the conversion of nitrate into proteins in the shoots of most plant species. One physiological mechanism responsible for this phenomenon involves photorespiration, a process through which sugars in a plant react with oxygen instead of CO2. Photorespiration has been erroneously portrayed as a wasteful process, but in fact, photorespiration generates energy necessary for converting nitrate into protein. Elevated CO2 decreases photorespiration, which leads to declines in plant protein concentrations, slower plant growth, and lower food value. The proposed research will examine how photorespiration transfers energy to convert nitrate into protein. It will examine the chemical structure of the enzymes that facilitate these reactions and to trace the flows of energy from one reaction to another. This information will provide a new perspective on the efficiency of photosynthesis and greater insight on the influence that rising CO2 will have on the distribution of plant species.

Rising CO2 concentration in the atmosphere inhibits NO3 assimilation into proteins in the shoots of C3 plants and impedes their growth when NO3 is the predominant N source. One process that links CO2 concentration to shoot NO3 assimilation is photorespiration. Photorespiration stimulates the export of malic acid from chloroplasts and increases the availability of NADH in the cytoplasm that empowers the reduction of NO3 to NO2, the first step of NO3 assimilation. CO2 enrichment decreases photorespiration, decreasing the amount of NADH available for NO3 reduction. The proposed research will examine this mechanism in greater detail. Nearly all studies of Rubisco are conducted in the presence of magnesium, which favors carboxylation, rather than in the presence of manganese, which favors oxygenation and electron transfers that might stimulate NADP+ reduction. The objectives of this research are: 1) use X-ray crystallography to confirm the locations of manganese and NADP+ within tobacco Rubisco, 2) identify via electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) the structural changes of transient enzyme-substrate complexes and catalytic reaction intermediates during photorespiration, and 3) conduct site-directed mutagenesis of residues in the catalytic large subunit of Rubisco that are involved with photorespiratory electron transfer to provide powerful structural probes. Energy transfers between photorespiration and nitrate assimilation should explain why over 95% of higher plant species still rely solely on C3 fixation even after more than 20 million years of relatively low atmospheric CO2 concentrations and multiple introductions of the C4 pathway: C3 fixation is more efficient than previously thought because photorespiration supports nitrate assimilation. Moreover, these mechanisms should explain why plant responses to elevated CO2 are highly variable: in C3 plants that are dependent on nitrate, CO2 inhibition of shoot nitrate assimilation causes organic N deficiencies and slows growth, whereas in C3 plants dependent on ammonium, elevated CO2 promotes growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous studies of plant photosynthesis and respiration have assumed that most plants dissipate over 30% of their energy as waste heat in a process known as photorespiration and that photorespiration has continued through the ages, because plants have reached an evolutionary dead-end. Based on this assumption, a major scientific objective has been to develop new cultivars that minimize photorespiration and that have the capacity to fix atmospheric nitrogen (e.g., to engineer C4 rice or nitrogen-fixing corn).

This project discovered that the energy expended during photorespiration is not wasted; rather it generates malic acid that serves as the energy source to convert nitrate that roots absorb from the soil into proteins within the shoots. Photorespiration, thus, allows plants to gain nearly exclusive use of soil nitrate as a nitrogen source, because soil microorganisms can seldom afford the energy to convert this low-energy nitrogen form into high-energy forms such as proteins. Rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations inhibit photorespiration, which in turn inhibits nitrate assimilation into proteins, and protein deficiencies ensue. An ever-expanding body of evidence supports the results of this project and highlights their value in predicting plant responses to the environmental conditions anticipated during the next few decades.

Our most recent experiments suggest a novel metabolic regulatory mechanism: the displacement of one metal for another in enzymes. In particular, the balance between the carbon fixation and photorespiration depends on several factors, but one that is usually ignored is the extent to which Rubisco, the most prevalent protein on the planet, associates with either manganese or magnesium. When Rubisco associates with manganese, it catalyzes the initial reactions of carbon fixation and photorespiration at similar rates, and manganese transfers electrons. When Rubisco associates with magnesium, the initial reaction of carbon fixation accelerates and proceeds four times faster than the initial reaction of photorespiration, but no electrons are transferred. All metals concentrations decline in plants exposed to elevated CO2 atmospheres except for manganese. This increase in manganese to magnesium ratio partially compensates for the decline in photorespiration at elevated CO2 and the concomitant decrease in nitrate assimilation. Consequently, regulation of manganese and magnesium mitigates detrimental changes in plant nitrogen/carbon balance as atmospheric CO2 concentrations vary.

The results of this project explain a wide range of phenomena.

  • Every test tube experiment on carbon fixation and photorespiration, with few exceptions during the past four decades, has been conducted in the absence of manganese and, thus, without photorespiratory electron transfers.
  • C3 carbon fixation, a pathway subject to photorespiration, is more efficient than previously thought because photorespiratory electron transfers empower nitrate assimilation. Consequently, over 95% of higher plant species still rely solely on C3 carbon fixation, despite more than 20 million years of relatively low atmospheric CO2 concentrations and over 60 independent introductions of CO2 concentrating mechanisms (e.g., C4 pathway).
  • Attempts over four decades to generate C4 rice and nitrogen-fixing corn have met with little success because C3 carbon fixation and nitrate assimilation are more efficient under nearly all growth conditions.
  • Plant responses to rising atmospheric CO2 concentration are highly variable and dependent on their nitrogen status. Plants vary greatly in their dependence on nitrate as a nitrogen source. Rising CO2 inhibits photorespiration, and so plants dependent on nitrate, assimilate less nitrate and suffer protein deficiencies.
  • The observed declines in forest health and food quality associated with climate change derive in part from CO2 inhibition of nitrate assimilation and the concomitant protein deficiencies. This exacerbates damage from insects and other pests as they consume more plant material to meet their nutritional needs.
